entry.et: Middle English, from Old English missan; akin to Old High German missan to miss

def.dt: :to fail to hit, reach, or contact miss the target
:to discover or feel the absence of
:to fail to obtain
:escape avoid just missed hitting the other car
:to leave out :omit
:to fail to comprehend, sense, or experience missed the point of the speech
:to fail to perform or attend had to miss school for a week
:to fail to get, reach, or do something
:to fail to hit something
:to be unsuccessful
:misfire the engine missed
:to deviate from regular smooth performance the company changed ownership without missing a beat
:to lose a good opportunity for missed out on a better job
:to fail to take advantage of an opportunity
:disadvantage or regret resulting from loss we know the miss of you, and even hunger … to see you Samuel Richardson
:a failure to hit
:a failure to attain a desired result
:misfire

dt.un: used as a title prefixed to the name of an unmarried woman or girl
used before the name of a place or of a line of activity or before some epithet to form a title for a usually young unmarried female who is representative of the thing indicated Miss America

def.dt: :young lady used without a name as a conventional term of address to a young woman
:a young unmarried woman or girl
:a clothing size for women of average height and build
:to leave out :omit
:certain to have a favorable result, performance, or reception :surefire a can't–miss prospect
:sometimes successful and sometimes not :not reliably good or successful
:in a hit-or-miss manner :haphazardly
:marked by a lack of care, forethought, system, or plan
:hit-and-miss
:an adolescent girl
:junior 1b
